text:
Welcome to another episode
of 'Back to Basics', everyone.
I'm Pratima Singh,

and I am here today to talk to you
about vulnerability management
but in an automated way.
Now, why, you might ask?

Well, in recent years, vulnerabilities
have taken the IT community by storm.
Every year there's a record-breaking number of vulnerabilities
that are recorded.

And with a number of application
development frameworks in play
and operating systems,

it can be a real struggle
to patch systems and applications.

But before we dive deeper,
let's form a collective understanding
of what vulnerabilities really are.

Vulnerabilities
don't just magically appear.
They have existed ever since software has.

As with most things,
we humans create them.

They are in the software we write
and in the configurations we build.
A large portion of vulnerabilities

is recorded
in the software that other humans write,

and such software
includes third party libraries

and operating systems
that help us run applications on servers.

And a major portion
of these vulnerabilities
is recorded in operating systems.

Now, earlier on in my career,
when I was a Systems Engineer,

I was responsible
for managing 100 plus servers

and deploying
applications on those servers.

Now, every so often I would
get informed about security updates
that I needed to install on those servers.
It used to take me hours, if not days,

to iterate over the inventory,
manually install updates on the servers,

build manual reports
and reach out to my leads for approval.

And even then, almost always,
I would have missed out a few servers.

Now as much as I could,
I automated the whole system

by building scripts that I would
manually run on those servers.

But then it took me time
to build the reports manually

and also testing because it added
members of the other team to test

and the security
teams for the final approval.

Now, involving other team
members added to the lead time.
As I started using AWS,

I came across
the AWS Systems Manager service.
AWS Systems Manager - That was a game changer for me.

I could manage on-premises servers
and Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud

or EC2 Instances alike
by installing a single agent.
Once the Amazon-SSM-agent was installed
servers and EC2 instances,

essentially the whole
inventory that I managed manually

was discovered
automatically as managed nodes.
With the inventory sorted,
I moved my attention to the Patch Manager.
I could ditch all my makeshift scripts
and use predefined patch baselines

for a range of Linux-based
and Windows operating systems,

including adding approval rules,
a task I used to manage manually.

Now, this reduced the time
I spent on managing patches on servers
to a matter of hours.

Now, as I explored
this service more and more,

I came across the feature
to schedule patching runs
using the maintenance Windows feature.
Now, I no longer had to sit

looking at installations
being done on server by server manually,
and the Patch Manager dashboard
gave me the compliance report automatically

that I used to spend hours
building to get my leads approvals.

As the development teams
started to work with containers,
it became an interesting challenge

to manage
vulnerabilities with Container Images.

Container Images
can be easily overwritten,
which can lead to loss of context

with changes along
with a layer development approach,

which can result
in vulnerabilities hiding in the layers

and only detectable
in the container run-time.

Interestingly, teams could
turn on the tag Immutability feature

in Amazon Elastic Container Registry
or Amazon ECR

to ensure that a container Image
cannot be overwritten by another image

using the same tag
but with different contents.

This ensured uniqueness
of each image pushed to the repository.

Now the teams could
also configure scanning of images
either on push or continually.

But the security team
wanted a single pane of glass view

of the security posture of the entire
IT environment in their organization.

Now, this is where Amazon Inspector
and AWS Security Hub, came in.

Now ECR forwards
all findings to Inspector,

which is an automated
vulnerability management service.

AWS Security Hub
natively integrates with AWS services
like Patch Manager and Amazon Inspector.

It supports cross-account
and cross-region aggregation.

Once all the findings
are consolidated in Security Hub,

the security team
could build insights, alerts,
and even trigger auto-remediation actions

using the custom actions
feature of Security Hub.

Now with Security Hub,
we have been able to tie
our vulnerability management solution
into a neat bow.
Now, in this episode,

we saw how we could build
a vulnerability management solution
in a hybrid environment with servers,
Amazon EC2 instances and Container Images.

We've used services
like AWS Systems Manager,

Amazon ECR,
Amazon Inspector, and AWS Security Hub.

Check out the links
below for more details.
See you next time.
